p: To mimic the real-life scenarios, we also account for the formation of groups of pedestrians. The groups’ formation is controlled by adjusting the distance ( δ) in Eq ( 2). Literature [ 35] indicates that pedestrian spacing is different between pedestrians belonging to a group (e.g. family or friends in the queue) and other pedestrians. An average distance of δ 1 = 0.46 m is chosen for pedestrian particles within the same group, while this distance between independent pedestrians is given a value of δ 2 = 0.64 m.
